parameters.name: q
parameters.description: Keyword search for item

parameters.name: additionaltype
parameters.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

parameters.name: aggregaterating
parameters.description: The overall rating, based on a collection of reviews or ratings, of the item.

parameters.name: alternatename
parameters.description: An alias for the item.

parameters.name: attendee
parameters.description: A person or organization attending the event. Supersedes attendees.

parameters.name: awayteam
parameters.description: The away team in a sports event.

parameters.name: competitor
parameters.description: A competitor in a sports event.

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: A short description of the item.

parameters.name: doortime
parameters.description: The time admission will commence.

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: The duration of the item (movie, audio recording, event, etc.) in ISO 8601 date format.

parameters.name: enddate
parameters.description: The end date and time of the item (in ISO 8601 date format).

parameters.name: eventstatus
parameters.description: An eventStatus of an event represents its status; particularly useful when an event is cancelled or rescheduled.

parameters.name: hometeam
parameters.description: The home team in a sports event.

parameters.name: image
parameters.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

parameters.name: inlanguage
parameters.description: The language of the content or performance or used in an action. Please use one of the language codes from the IETF BCP 47 standard. Supersedes language.

parameters.name: location
parameters.description: The location of for example where the event is happening, an organization is located, or where an action takes place.

parameters.name: mainentityofpage
parameters.description: Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the item.

parameters.name: offers
parameters.description: An offer to provide this item—for example, an offer to sell a product, rent the DVD of a movie, perform a service, or give away tickets to an event.

parameters.name: organizer
parameters.description: An organizer of an Event.

parameters.name: performer
parameters.description: A performer at the event—for example, a presenter, musician, musical group or actor. Supersedes performers.

parameters.name: potentialaction
parameters.description: Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

parameters.name: previousstartdate
parameters.description: Used in conjunction with eventStatus for rescheduled or cancelled events. This property contains the previously scheduled start date. For rescheduled events, the startDate property should be used for the newly scheduled start date. In the (rare) case of an event that has been postponed and rescheduled multiple times, this field may be repeated.

parameters.name: recordedin
parameters.description: The CreativeWork that captured all or part of this Event. Inverse property: recordedAt.

parameters.name: review
parameters.description: A review of the item. Supersedes reviews.

parameters.name: sameas
parameters.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

parameters.name: sportsevent
parameters.description: A sub property of location. The sports event where this action occurred.

parameters.name: startdate
parameters.description: The start date and time of the item (in ISO 8601 date format).

parameters.name: subevent
parameters.description: An Event that is part of this event. For example, a conference event includes many presentations, each of which is a subEvent of the conference. Supersedes subEvents.

parameters.name: superevent
parameters.description: An event that this event is a part of. For example, a collection of individual music performances might each have a music festival as their superEvent.

parameters.name: typicalagerange
parameters.description: The typical expected age range, e.g. '7-9', '11-'.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: URL of the item.

parameters.name: workfeatured
parameters.description: A work featured in some event, e.g. exhibited in an ExhibitionEvent.       Specific subproperties are available for workPerformed (e.g. a play), or a workPresented (a Movie at a ScreeningEvent).

parameters.name: workperformed
parameters.description: A work performed in some event, for example a play performed in a TheaterEvent.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique id for item

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique id for item

parameters.name: additionaltype
parameters.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

description.description: The subject matter of the content.
Indicates that the resource is compatible with the referenced accessibility API (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).
Identifies input methods that are sufficient to fully control the described resource (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).
Content features of the resource, such as accessible media, alternatives and supported enhancements for accessibility (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).
A characteristic of the described resource that is physiologically dangerous to some users. Related to WCAG 2.0 guideline 2.3 (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).
Specifies the Person that is legally accountable for the CreativeWork.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
The overall rating, based on a collection of reviews or ratings, of the item.
An alias for the item.
A secondary title of the CreativeWork.
The actual body of the article.
Articles may belong to one or more 'sections' in a magazine or newspaper, such as Sports, Lifestyle, etc.
A media object that encodes this CreativeWork. This property is a synonym for encoding.
An intended audience, i.e. a group for whom something was created. Supersedes serviceAudience.
An embedded audio object.

The author of this content. Please note that author is special in that HTML 5 provides a special mechanism for indicating authorship via the rel tag. That is equivalent to this and may be used interchangeably.
An award won by or for this item. Supersedes awards.
Fictional person connected with a creative work.
A citation or reference to another creative work, such as another publication, web page, scholarly article, etc.
Comments, typically from users.

The number of comments this CreativeWork (e.g. Article, Question or Answer) has received. This is most applicable to works published in Web sites with commenting system; additional comments may exist elsewhere.
The location depicted or described in the content. For example, the location in a photograph or painting.
Official rating of a piece of content—for example,'MPAA PG-13'.
A secondary contributor to the CreativeWork.
The party holding the legal copyright to the CreativeWork.
The year during which the claimed copyright for the CreativeWork was first asserted.
The creator/author of this CreativeWork. This is the same as the Author property for CreativeWork.
The date on which the CreativeWork was created or the item was added to a DataFeed.
The date on which the CreativeWork was most recently modified or when the item's entry was modified within a DataFeed.
Date of first broadcast/publication.
A short description of the item.
A link to the page containing the comments of the CreativeWork.
Specifies the Person who edited the CreativeWork.
An alignment to an established educational framework.
The purpose of a work in the context of education; for example, 'assignment', 'group work'.
A media object that encodes this CreativeWork. This property is a synonym for associatedMedia. Supersedes encodings.
A creative work that this work is an example/instance/realization/derivation of. Inverse property: workExample.

Media type (aka MIME format, see IANA site) of the content e.g. application/zip of a SoftwareApplication binary. In cases where a CreativeWork has several media type representations, 'encoding' can be used to indicate each MediaObject alongside particular fileFormat information.
Genre of the creative work or group.
Indicates a CreativeWork that is (in some sense) a part of this CreativeWork. Inverse property: isPartOf.
Headline of the article.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
The language of the content or performance or used in an action. Please use one of the language codes from the IETF BCP 47 standard. Supersedes language.
The number of interactions for the CreativeWork using the WebSite or SoftwareApplication. The most specific child type of InteractionCounter should be used. Supersedes interactionCount.
The predominant mode of learning supported by the learning resource. Acceptable values are 'active', 'expositive', or 'mixed'.
A resource that was used in the creation of this resource. This term can be repeated for multiple sources. For example, http://example.com/great-multiplication-intro.html.
Indicates whether this content is family friendly.
Indicates a CreativeWork that this CreativeWork is (in some sense) part of. Inverse property: hasPart.
Keywords or tags used to describe this content. Multiple entries in a keywords list are typically delimited by commas.
The predominant type or kind characterizing the learning resource. For example, 'presentation', 'handout'.
A license document that applies to this content, typically indicated by URL.
The location where the CreativeWork was created, which may not be the same as the location depicted in the CreativeWork.
Indicates the primary entity described in some page or other CreativeWork. Inverse property: mainEntityOfPage.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
Indicates that the CreativeWork contains a reference to, but is not necessarily about a concept.
The name of the item.
An offer to provide this item—for example, an offer to sell a product, rent the DVD of a movie, perform a service, or give away tickets to an event.
The page on which the work ends; for example "138" or "xvi".
The page on which the work starts; for example "135" or "xiii".
Any description of pages that is not separated into pageStart and pageEnd; for example, "1-6, 9, 55" or "10-12, 46-49".
The position of an item in a series or sequence of items.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
The person or organization who produced the work (e.g. music album, movie, tv/radio series etc.).

The service provider, service operator, or service performer; the goods producer. Another party (a seller) may offer those services or goods on behalf of the provider. A provider may also serve as the seller. Supersedes carrier.
A publication event associated with the item.
The publisher of the creative work.
Link to page describing the editorial principles of the organization primarily responsible for the creation of the CreativeWork.
The Event where the CreativeWork was recorded. The CreativeWork may capture all or part of the event. Inverse property: recordedIn.
The place and time the release was issued, expressed as a PublicationEvent.
A review of the item. Supersedes reviews.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

Indicates (by URL or string) a particular version of a schema used in some CreativeWork. For example, a document could declare a schemaVersion using a URL such as http://schema.org/version/2.0/ if precise indication of schema version was required by some application.
A CreativeWork such as an image, video, or audio clip shared as part of this posting.
The Organization on whose behalf the creator was working.
The textual content of this CreativeWork.
A thumbnail image relevant to the Thing.
Approximate or typical time it takes to work with or through this learning resource for the typical intended target audience, e.g. 'P30M', 'P1H25M'.
Organization or person who adapts a creative work to different languages, regional differences and technical requirements of a target market.
The typical expected age range, e.g. '7-9', '11-'.
URL of the item.
The version of the CreativeWork embodied by a specified resource.
An embedded video object.
The number of words in the text of the Article.
Example/instance/realization/derivation of the concept of this creative work. eg. The paperback edition, first edition, or eBook. Inverse property: exampleOfWork.
The subject matter of the content.
Indicates that the resource is compatible with the referenced accessibility API (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).
Identifies input methods that are sufficient to fully control the described resource (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).
Content features of the resource, such as accessible media, alternatives and supported enhancements for accessibility (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).
A characteristic of the described resource that is physiologically dangerous to some users. Related to WCAG 2.0 guideline 2.3 (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).
Specifies the Person that is legally accountable for the CreativeWork.
An application that can complete the request.  Supersedes application.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
The overall rating, based on a collection of reviews or ratings, of the item.
An alias for the item.
A secondary title of the CreativeWork.
Type of software application, e.g. "Game, Multimedia".
Subcategory of the application, e.g. "Arcade Game".
The name of the application suite to which the application belongs (e.g. Excel belongs to Office).
A media object that encodes this CreativeWork. This property is a synonym for encoding.
An intended audience, i.e. a group for whom something was created. Supersedes serviceAudience.
An embedded audio object.

The author of this content. Please note that author is special in that HTML 5 provides a special mechanism for indicating authorship via the rel tag. That is equivalent to this and may be used interchangeably.
Device required to run the application. Used in cases where a specific make/model is required to run the application. Supersedes device.
An award won by or for this item. Supersedes awards.
Fictional person connected with a creative work.
A citation or reference to another creative work, such as another publication, web page, scholarly article, etc.
Comments, typically from users.

The number of comments this CreativeWork (e.g. Article, Question or Answer) has received. This is most applicable to works published in Web sites with commenting system; additional comments may exist elsewhere.
The location depicted or described in the content. For example, the location in a photograph or painting.
Official rating of a piece of content—for example,'MPAA PG-13'.
A secondary contributor to the CreativeWork.
The party holding the legal copyright to the CreativeWork.
The year during which the claimed copyright for the CreativeWork was first asserted.
Countries for which the application is not supported. You can also provide the two-letter ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code.
Countries for which the application is supported. You can also provide the two-letter ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code.
The creator/author of this CreativeWork. This is the same as the Author property for CreativeWork.
The date on which the CreativeWork was created or the item was added to a DataFeed.
The date on which the CreativeWork was most recently modified or when the item's entry was modified within a DataFeed.
Date of first broadcast/publication.
A short description of the item.
A link to the page containing the comments of the CreativeWork.
If the file can be downloaded, URL to download the binary.
Specifies the Person who edited the CreativeWork.
An alignment to an established educational framework.
The purpose of a work in the context of education; for example, 'assignment', 'group work'.
A media object that encodes this CreativeWork. This property is a synonym for associatedMedia. Supersedes encodings.
A creative work that this work is an example/instance/realization/derivation of. Inverse property: workExample.
Features or modules provided by this application (and possibly required by other applications).

Media type (aka MIME format, see IANA site) of the content e.g. application/zip of a SoftwareApplication binary. In cases where a CreativeWork has several media type representations, 'encoding' can be used to indicate each MediaObject alongside particular fileFormat information.
Size of the application / package (e.g. 18MB). In the absence of a unit (MB, KB etc.), KB will be assumed.
Genre of the creative work or group.
Indicates a CreativeWork that is (in some sense) a part of this CreativeWork. Inverse property: isPartOf.
Headline of the article.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
The language of the content or performance or used in an action. Please use one of the language codes from the IETF BCP 47 standard. Supersedes language.
URL at which the app may be installed, if different from the URL of the item.
The WebSite or SoftwareApplication where the interactions took place.
The number of interactions for the CreativeWork using the WebSite or SoftwareApplication. The most specific child type of InteractionCounter should be used. Supersedes interactionCount.
The predominant mode of learning supported by the learning resource. Acceptable values are 'active', 'expositive', or 'mixed'.
A resource that was used in the creation of this resource. This term can be repeated for multiple sources. For example, http://example.com/great-multiplication-intro.html.
Indicates whether this content is family friendly.
Indicates a CreativeWork that this CreativeWork is (in some sense) part of. Inverse property: hasPart.
Keywords or tags used to describe this content. Multiple entries in a keywords list are typically delimited by commas.
The predominant type or kind characterizing the learning resource. For example, 'presentation', 'handout'.
A license document that applies to this content, typically indicated by URL.
The location where the CreativeWork was created, which may not be the same as the location depicted in the CreativeWork.
Indicates the primary entity described in some page or other CreativeWork. Inverse property: mainEntityOfPage.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
Minimum memory requirements.
Indicates that the CreativeWork contains a reference to, but is not necessarily about a concept.
The name of the item.
An offer to provide this item—for example, an offer to sell a product, rent the DVD of a movie, perform a service, or give away tickets to an event.
Operating systems supported (Windows 7, OSX 10.6, Android 1.6).
Permission(s) required to run the app (for example, a mobile app may require full internet access or may run only on wifi).
The position of an item in a series or sequence of items.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
Processor architecture required to run the application (e.g. IA64).
The person or organization who produced the work (e.g. music album, movie, tv/radio series etc.).

The service provider, service operator, or service performer; the goods producer. Another party (a seller) may offer those services or goods on behalf of the provider. A provider may also serve as the seller. Supersedes carrier.

Indicates (by URL or string) a particular version of a schema used in some CreativeWork. For example, a document could declare a schemaVersion using a URL such as http://schema.org/version/2.0/ if precise indication of schema version was required by some application.
A link to a screenshot image of the app.
Additional content for a software application.
Software application help.

Component dependency requirements for application. This includes runtime environments and shared libraries that are not included in the application distribution package, but required to run the application (Examples: DirectX, Java or .NET runtime). Supersedes requirements.
Version of the software instance.
The Organization on whose behalf the creator was working.
Storage requirements (free space required).
Supporting data for a SoftwareApplication.
Target Operating System / Product to which the code applies.  If applies to several versions, just the product name can be used.

The service provider, service operator, or service performer; the goods producer. Another party (a seller) may offer those services or goods on behalf of the provider. A provider may also serve as the seller. Supersedes carrier.
A publication event associated with the item.
The publisher of the creative work.
Link to page describing the editorial principles of the organization primarily responsible for the creation of the CreativeWork.
The Event where the CreativeWork was recorded. The CreativeWork may capture all or part of the event. Inverse property: recordedIn.
The place and time the release was issued, expressed as a PublicationEvent.
A review of the item. Supersedes reviews.
Runtime platform or script interpreter dependencies (Example - Java v1, Python2.3, .Net Framework 3.0). Supersedes runtime.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

Indicates (by URL or string) a particular version of a schema used in some CreativeWork. For example, a document could declare a schemaVersion using a URL such as http://schema.org/version/2.0/ if precise indication of schema version was required by some application.
The Organization on whose behalf the creator was working.
Target Operating System / Product to which the code applies.  If applies to several versions, just the product name can be used.
The textual content of this CreativeWork.
A thumbnail image relevant to the Thing.
Approximate or typical time it takes to work with or through this learning resource for the typical intended target audience, e.g. 'P30M', 'P1H25M'.
Organization or person who adapts a creative work to different languages, regional differences and technical requirements of a target market.
The typical expected age range, e.g. '7-9', '11-'.
URL of the item.
The version of the CreativeWork embodied by a specified resource.
An embedded video object.
Example/instance/realization/derivation of the concept of this creative work. eg. The paperback edition, first edition, or eBook. Inverse property: exampleOfWork.

A property-value pair representing an additional characteristics of the entitity, e.g. a product feature or another characteristic for which there is no matching property in schema.org. Note: Publishers should be aware that applications designed to use specific schema.org properties (e.g. http://schema.org/width, http://schema.org/color, http://schema.org/gtin13, ...) will typically expect such data to be provided using those properties, rather than using the generic property/value mechanism.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
The overall rating, based on a collection of reviews or ratings, of the item.
An alias for the item.
An intended audience, i.e. a group for whom something was created. Supersedes serviceAudience.
An award won by or for this item. Supersedes awards.
The brand(s) associated with a product or service, or the brand(s) maintained by an organization or business person.
A category for the item. Greater signs or slashes can be used to informally indicate a category hierarchy.
The color of the product.
The depth of the item.
A short description of the item.

The GTIN-12 code of the product, or the product to which the offer refers. The GTIN-12 is the 12-digit GS1 Identification Key composed of a U.P.C. Company Prefix, Item Reference, and Check Digit used to identify trade items. See GS1 GTIN Summary for more details.

The GTIN-13 code of the product, or the product to which the offer refers. This is equivalent to 13-digit ISBN codes and EAN UCC-13. Former 12-digit UPC codes can be converted into a GTIN-13 code by simply adding a preceeding zero. See GS1 GTIN Summary for more details.
The GTIN-14 code of the product, or the product to which the offer refers. See GS1 GTIN Summary for more details.
The GTIN-8 code of the product, or the product to which the offer refers. This code is also known as EAN/UCC-8 or 8-digit EAN. See GS1 GTIN Summary for more details.
The height of the item.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
The current approximate inventory level for the item or items.
A pointer to another product (or multiple products) for which this product is an accessory or spare part.
A pointer to another product (or multiple products) for which this product is a consumable.
A pointer to another, somehow related product (or multiple products).
A pointer to another, functionally similar product (or multiple products).
A predefined value from OfferItemCondition or a textual description of the condition of the product or service, or the products or services included in the offer.
An associated logo.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The manufacturer of the product.

The model of the product. Use with the URL of a ProductModel or a textual representation of the model identifier. The URL of the ProductModel can be from an external source. It is recommended to additionally provide strong product identifiers via the gtin8/gtin13/gtin14 and mpn properties.
The Manufacturer Part Number (MPN) of the product, or the product to which the offer refers.
The name of the item.
An offer to provide this item—for example, an offer to sell a product, rent the DVD of a movie, perform a service, or give away tickets to an event.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
The product identifier, such as ISBN. For example: <meta itemprop='productID' content='isbn:123-456-789'/>.
The date of production of the item, e.g. vehicle.
The date the item e.g. vehicle was purchased by the current owner.
The release date of a product or product model. This can be used to distinguish the exact variant of a product.
A review of the item. Supersedes reviews.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
The Stock Keeping Unit (SKU), i.e. a merchant-specific identifier for a product or service, or the product to which the offer refers.
URL of the item.
The weight of the product or person.
The width of the item.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
An alias for the item.
A short description of the item.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The name of the item.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
One of the domain specialities to which this web page's content applies.
Relates a term (i.e. a property, class or enumeration) to one that supersedes it.
URL of the item.

A property-value pair representing an additional characteristics of the entitity, e.g. a product feature or another characteristic for which there is no matching property in schema.org. Note: Publishers should be aware that applications designed to use specific schema.org properties (e.g. http://schema.org/width, http://schema.org/color, http://schema.org/gtin13, ...) will typically expect such data to be provided using those properties, rather than using the generic property/value mechanism.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
Physical address of the item.
The overall rating, based on a collection of reviews or ratings, of the item.
An alias for the item.
Alumni of an organization. Inverse property: alumniOf.

name.type: text or  place or  geoshape or  administrativearea

description.description: The geographic area where a service or offered item is provided. Supersedes serviceArea.
description.type: text or  place or  geoshape or  administrativearea

description.description: An award won by or for this item. Supersedes awards.

A short textual code (also called "store code") that uniquely identifies a place of business. The code is typically assigned by the parentOrganization and used in structured URLs. For example, in the URL http://www.starbucks.co.uk/store-locator/etc/detail/3047 the code "3047" is a branchCode for a particular branch.
The brand(s) associated with a product or service, or the brand(s) maintained by an organization or business person.
A contact point for a person or organization. Supersedes contactPoints.
The basic containment relation between a place and one that contains it. Supersedes containedIn. Inverse property: containsPlace.
The basic containment relation between a place and another that it contains. Inverse property: containsPlace.
The currency accepted (in ISO 4217 currency format).

A relationship between an organization and a department of that organization, also described as an organization (allowing different urls, logos, opening hours). For example: a store with a pharmacy, or a bakery with a cafe.
A short description of the item.
The date that this organization was dissolved.
The Dun & Bradstreet DUNS number for identifying an organization or business person.
Email address.
Someone working for this organization. Supersedes employees.
Upcoming or past event associated with this place, organization, or action. Supersedes events.
The fax number.
A person who founded this organization. Supersedes founders.
The date that this organization was founded.
The place where the Organization was founded.
The geo coordinates of the place.

The Global Location Number (GLN, sometimes also referred to as International Location Number or ILN) of the respective organization, person, or place. The GLN is a 13-digit number used to identify parties and physical locations.
A URL to a map of the place. Supersedes map, maps.
Indicates an OfferCatalog listing for this Organization, Person, or Service.
Points-of-Sales operated by the organization or person.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
The International Standard of Industrial Classification of All Economic Activities (ISIC), Revision 4 code for a particular organization, business person, or place.
The official name of the organization, e.g. the registered company name.
The location of for example where the event is happening, an organization is located, or where an action takes place.
An associated logo.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
A pointer to products or services offered by the organization or person. Inverse property: offeredBy.

A member of an Organization or a ProgramMembership. Organizations can be members of organizations; ProgramMembership is typically for individuals. Supersedes musicGroupMember, members. Inverse property: memberOf.
An Organization (or ProgramMembership) to which this Person or Organization belongs. Inverse property: member.
The North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code for a particular organization or business person.
The name of the item.
The number of employees in an organization e.g. business.

The opening hours for a business. Opening hours can be specified as a weekly time range, starting with days, then times per day. Multiple days can be listed with commas ',' separating each day. Day or time ranges are specified using a hyphen '-'.- Days are specified using the following two-letter combinations: Mo, Tu, We, Th, Fr, Sa, Su.- Times are specified using 24:00 time. For example, 3pm is specified as 15:00. - Here is an example: <time itemprop="openingHours" datetime="Tu,Th 16:00-20:00">Tuesdays and Thursdays 4-8pm</time>. - If a business is open 7 days a week, then it can be specified as <time itemprop="openingHours" datetime="Mo-Su">Monday through Sunday, all day</time>.
The opening hours of a certain place.
Products owned by the organization or person.
The larger organization that this organization is a branch of, if any. Supersedes branchOf. Inverse property: subOrganization.
Cash, credit card, etc.
A photograph of this place. Supersedes photos.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
The price range of the business, for example $$$.
A review of the item. Supersedes reviews.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
A pointer to products or services sought by the organization or person (demand).
A relationship between two organizations where the first includes the second, e.g., as a subsidiary. See also: the more specific 'department' property. Inverse property: parentOrganization.
The Tax / Fiscal ID of the organization or person, e.g. the TIN in the US or the CIF/NIF in Spain.
The telephone number.
URL of the item.
The Value-added Tax ID of the organization or person.

A property-value pair representing an additional characteristics of the entitity, e.g. a product feature or another characteristic for which there is no matching property in schema.org. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
Physical address of the item.
The overall rating, based on a collection of reviews or ratings, of the item.
An alias for the item.
Alumni of an organization. Inverse property: alumniOf.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
The overall rating, based on a collection of reviews or ratings, of the item.
An alias for the item.
A person or organization attending the event. Supersedes attendees.
The away team in a sports event.
A competitor in a sports event.
A short description of the item.
The time admission will commence.
The duration of the item (movie, audio recording, event, etc.) in ISO 8601 date format.
The end date and time of the item (in ISO 8601 date format).
An eventStatus of an event represents its status; particularly useful when an event is cancelled or rescheduled.
The home team in a sports event.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
The language of the content or performance or used in an action. Please use one of the language codes from the IETF BCP 47 standard. Supersedes language.
The location of for example where the event is happening, an organization is located, or where an action takes place.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The name of the item.
An offer to provide this item—for example, an offer to sell a product, rent the DVD of a movie, perform a service, or give away tickets to an event.
An organizer of an Event.
A performer at the event—for example, a presenter, musician, musical group or actor. Supersedes performers.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

Used in conjunction with eventStatus for rescheduled or cancelled events. This property contains the previously scheduled start date. For rescheduled events, the startDate property should be used for the newly scheduled start date. In the (rare) case of an event that has been postponed and rescheduled multiple times, this field may be repeated.
The CreativeWork that captured all or part of this Event. Inverse property: recordedAt.
A review of the item. Supersedes reviews.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
A sub property of location. The sports event where this action occurred.
The start date and time of the item (in ISO 8601 date format).
An Event that is part of this event. For example, a conference event includes many presentations, each of which is a subEvent of the conference. Supersedes subEvents.
An event that this event is a part of. For example, a collection of individual music performances might each have a music festival as their superEvent.
The typical expected age range, e.g. '7-9', '11-'.
URL of the item.
A work featured in some event, e.g. exhibited in an ExhibitionEvent.       Specific subproperties are available for workPerformed (e.g. a play), or a workPresented (a Movie at a ScreeningEvent).
A work performed in some event, for example a play performed in a TheaterEvent.
